dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Boris Johnson's steel and aluminum tariffs, citing national security, really ruffled feathers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Boris Johnson's steel and aluminum tariffs, citing national security, really ruffled feathers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When former US President Donald Trump, citing national-security concerns, imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, many of the United States trading partners viewed this as a fig leaf for protectionism and filed complaints with the WTO.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, that was seen as a total protectionist move, right? And then the UK refusing to appoint new WTO judges just left everyone in limbo.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, that was seen as a total protectionist move, right? And then the U K refusing to appoint new W T O judges just left everyone in limbo.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Americas refusal to appoint new judges to the WTOs dispute-settlement body has left members without a functional mechanism to resolve such conflicts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's like the dispute-settlement mechanism just... stopped functioning. But then you look at sanctions—like those against Russia—and it's a whole other can of worms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's like the dispute-settlement mechanism just... stopped functioning. But then you look at sanctions-like those against Russia-and it's a whole other can of worms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Americas refusal to appoint new judges to the WTOs dispute-settlement body has left members without a functional mechanism to resolve such conflicts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm. The price cap on Russian oil, what was it, seventy dollars a barrel? That actually seemed to work for a while.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm. The price cap on Russian oil, what was it, seventy dollars a barrel? That actually seemed to work for a while.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They also introduced a $60-per-barrel price cap on Russian oil, designed to cripple Russias economy while ensuring that Europe could avoid a politically destabilizing energy crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It did! By late 2023, the price had dropped to like fifty-five dollars. But then you've got these workarounds—shadow fleets, rerouting through third countries...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It did! By late twenty twenty three, the price had dropped to like fifty-five dollars. But then you've got these workarounds-shadow fleets, rerouting through third countries...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While financial sanctions forced oil traders to secure ships with suitable insurance coverage before finalizing transactions, the price of Russian oil did not fall below $60 per barrel. By November 2023, it had risen to $84.20 as Russian companies developed various methods of circumventing Western restrictions, such as inflated shipping costs and a shadow fleet consisting of more than 100 old tankers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Iran and China are masters at that. Building legitimate-looking networks to bypass restrictions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Iran and China are masters at that. Building legitimate-looking networks to bypass restrictions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Iran, for example, has managed to circumvent Western sanctions by constructing a sophisticated oil-smuggling network. Similarly, sanctioned Chinese goods are reportedly still entering the US market, as China-based firms reroute their exports through countries like Vietnam and Mexico.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the flip side—the humanitarian cost argument. Some analysts, um, Hanania from Cato, argued sanctions are actually pretty effective than we think, with minimal collateral damage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the flip side-the humanitarian cost argument. Some analysts, um, Hanania from Cato, argued sanctions are actually pretty effective than we think, with minimal collateral damage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Richard Hanania observed in a 2020 Cato Institute analysis, US-imposed trade sanctions almost always fail to achieve their goals. Moreover, sanctions have massive humanitarian costs and are not only ineffective but likely counterproductive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then you see reports of sanctioned goods still entering markets, like Chinese products coming through Russia and Belarus into Europe. It's not airtight.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you see reports of sanctioned goods still entering markets, like Chinese products coming through Russia and Belarus into Europe. It's not airtight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True. And financial sanctions? They've decreased over the past twenty years because they're harder to enforce globally. The euro's role in finance isn't as dominant as the dollar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True. And financial sanctions? They've decreased over the past twenty years because they're harder to enforce globally. The euro's role in finance isn't as dominant as the dollar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Consequently, US-imposed sanctions have increased tenfold over the past 20 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which brings up another point—the long-term risk of overusing dollar-based sanctions. Pushing other countries to find alternatives to SWIFT, to the dollar itself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which brings up another point-the long-term risk of overusing dollar-based sanctions. Pushing other countries to find alternatives to S W I F T, to the dollar itself.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the longer the global financial system is used as a tool of economic warfare, the more governments and businesses in third-party countries will look for alternatives to the dollar, euro, and the SWIFT international payment system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so even if sanctions work now, they might weaken the system that makes them possible in the future.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so even if sanctions work now, they might weaken the system that makes them possible in the future.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's such a delicate balance. You want to pressure bad actors without, uh, undermining the whole global economic framework.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's such a delicate balance. You want to pressure bad actors without, uh, undermining the whole global economic framework.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And yet, with Russia, the sanctions regime has kinda... worked? Revenues up, but also compliance is weirdly high?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And yet, with Russia, the sanctions regime has kinda... worked? Revenues up, but also compliance is weirdly high?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, Western sanctions have reduced Russias revenues and dented its GDP, albeit to a lesser extent than many had hoped.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, some companies just keep operating under the same name even after being sanctioned. One Dutch firm refused to sell to the US military!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, some companies just keep operating under the same name even after being sanctioned. One Dutch firm refused to sell to the U S military!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When a company is identified and sanctioned, a new company, operating under a different name, often takes its place. One Greek company even sold Russian oil to the US military.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Wild. So enforcement is patchy, but the overall strategy might still be doing what it's supposed to?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wild. So enforcement is patchy, but the overall strategy might still be doing what it's supposed to?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For now, maybe. But I don't think anyone's calling it a perfect solution.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For now, maybe. But I don't think anyone's calling it a perfect solution.

artist_script:
HostA: Boris Johnson's steel and aluminum tariffs, citing national security, really ruffled feathers.
HostB: Oh yeah, that was seen as a total protectionist move, right? And then the UK refusing to appoint new WTO judges just left everyone in limbo.
HostA: Exactly. It's like the dispute-settlement mechanism just... stopped functioning. But then you look at sanctions—like those against Russia—and it's a whole other can of worms.
HostB: Mhm. The price cap on Russian oil, what was it, seventy dollars a barrel? That actually seemed to work for a while.
HostA: It did! By late 2023, the price had dropped to like fifty-five dollars. But then you've got these workarounds—shadow fleets, rerouting through third countries...
HostB: Yeah, Iran and China are masters at that. Building legitimate-looking networks to bypass restrictions.
HostA: And then there's the flip side—the humanitarian cost argument. Some analysts, um, Hanania from Cato, argued sanctions are actually pretty effective than we think, with minimal collateral damage.
HostB: But then you see reports of sanctioned goods still entering markets, like Chinese products coming through Russia and Belarus into Europe. It’s not airtight.
HostA: True. And financial sanctions? They’ve decreased over the past twenty years because they’re harder to enforce globally. The euro’s role in finance isn’t as dominant as the dollar.
HostB: Which brings up another point—the long-term risk of overusing dollar-based sanctions. Pushing other countries to find alternatives to SWIFT, to the dollar itself.
HostA: Right, so even if sanctions work now, they might weaken the system that makes them possible in the future.
HostB: It’s such a delicate balance. You want to pressure bad actors without, uh, undermining the whole global economic framework.
HostA: And yet, with Russia, the sanctions regime has kinda... worked? Revenues up, but also compliance is weirdly high?
HostB: Yeah, some companies just keep operating under the same name even after being sanctioned. One Dutch firm refused to sell to the US military!
HostA: Wild. So enforcement is patchy, but the overall strategy might still be doing what it’s supposed to?
HostB: For now, maybe. But I don’t think anyone’s calling it a perfect solution.
